quoteLast: , V Battery, R.H.A., came into action on the left bank, and the Turks shortly afterwards withdrew their guns.

quoteFirst: Such was the aspect of the day, though the scene was in the south of France, at a spot which we shall leave for the present nameless, when at
quoteTime: about seven o'clock in the morning
quoteLast: --an hour in which, at that period of the year, the sun's rays are weak and powerless--a tall, strong, florid man of about four-and-thirty years of age was seen upon the edge of a wide wood walking along cautiously step by step, carefully bending down his eyes upon the withered leaves that strewed his path, as if he had dropped something of value which he sought to find.
title: Henry of Guise; or, The States of Blois (Vol. 1 of 3)

quoteFirst: Disconnected and irrelevant things kept coming into his mind: at one minute he thought of the old clock which used to hang on his wall fifteen years ago in Petersburg and had lost the minute-hand; at another of the cheerful clerk, Millebois, and how they had once caught a sparrow together in Alexandrovsky Park and had laughed so that they could be heard all over the park, remembering that one of them was already a college assessor. I imagine that
quoteLast: he must have fallen asleep without being aware of it himself, and must have slept with enjoyment, with agreeable dreams.

quoteTime: about seven o'clock in the morning
quoteLast: , I started from Gracechurch-street on the box of a stage coach, for Deal, where I was to join my regiment (from which I had been six weeks absent), and to proceed with it upon the “_secret_ expedition.” I took with me one good-sized trunk, pretty well stocked, and a cocked-hat case, which contained its proper lodger, one epaulette, two feathers, two black silk handkerchiefs, two pairs of white leather gloves, hat and hair brushes.
title:
The Military Sketch-Book. Vol. 1 (of 2)

quoteFirst: A most decided change seemed to have taken place; still the barometer remained as low as on the previous evening. A slight breeze from south-east changed to north, and at
quoteLast: the rain began to fall. Clouds of nimbus closed on the woody horizon, and we had a day of rain. In the evening the barometer had fallen still lower, and it was probable that the rain might continue through the night. Range of thermometer from 74° to 72°.

quoteFirst: The next day, January 23rd, His Highness’s secretary had arranged to send a carriage for us quite early (
quoteLast: ), to take us to see the ghats. When we reached the river side, which is a considerable drive from the Guest House, we found a beautiful state barge awaiting us.
title: India Impressions, With some notes of Ceylon during a winter tour, 1906-7.

quoteFirst: The charge is 260 barrels, and the following is an outline of the method of working. Assuming the still to be charged on Monday morning, heating is commenced
quoteLast: , and the naphtha begins to come over about 8 A.M. Of this product about six barrels is obtained in the case of Petrolia crude, or 7½ barrels in the case of Oil Springs crude. The distillation of the naphtha takes from 2 to 3 hours, say till 10:30 A.M. The heat is then increased, and the distillation of the kerosene commences about noon, and continues till about 10 P.M. Of the kerosene distillate about 80 barrels are obtained.
title: Scientific American Supplement, No. 611, September 17, 1887
author: Various

quoteFirst: It rained all night, and I awoke
quoteTime: about seven o'clock in the morning
quoteLast: shivering with cold. It was Ascension-day, and l'Encuerado, before making up the fire, chanted a canticle, and, after the manner of Roman Catholics, piously crossed himself.
title: Adventures of a Young Naturalist

quoteFirst: He said to me in the same manner that he had arrived at the Tuileries with his workmen and materials at six o’clock in the morning; that everything was so well constructed and put up that the King had not heard a sound; that his chief valet de chambre, having left the room for some commission
quoteTime: about seven o’clock in the morning
quoteLast: , had been much astonished upon seeing this apparatus; that the Marechal de Villeroy had only heard of it through him, and that the seats had been erected with such little noise that nobody had heard anything.  After having well examined everything with my eyes I advanced to the throne, then being finished; wishing to enter the second ante-chamber, some servants came to me, saying that I could not go in, all being locked up.
title: Memoirs of Louis XIV and His Court and of the Regency — Complete
author: Saint-Simon, Louis de Rouvroy, duc de, 1675-1755

quoteLast: , the duke, having received intelligence of the Prince Maréchal Blucher's retreat to Wavre, commenced a retreat on his part towards Waterloo, in order to recover his communication with the Prussians, and resume the execution of the plan of co-operation, which had been in some degree disconcerted by the sudden irruption of the French, and the loss of the battle of Ligny by the Prussians.
title: Life of Napoleon Bonaparte, Volume V.

quoteLast: of October tenth, Higinbotham’s thirty-third birthday.
